p: Olivia Banner’s chapter on Facebook’s attempt to develop biopsychosocial algorithms for its user base addresses these considerations in the current moment, and, therefore, opens the second section, “Digital Virality.” Her essay begins, like Thibault’s, by tracking researchers’ concerns that mass media produces a contaminated population that spreads media influence contagiously. Using Facebook’s recent suicide prevention protocol as a case study, she contends that Facebook’s deployment of such tools is part of the logic by which new media corporations justify themselves as “benevolent providers to public health officials.” By yoking their endeavors to those of public health and using epidemiological discourse to do so, social networking sites manage to stay relevant and seemingly integral to the modern world of digital virality.
